Synthesis and characterization of highly stable superparamagnetic CoFe2O4 nanoparticles as a catalyst for novel synthesis of thiazolo[4,5-b]quinolin-9-one derivatives in aqueous medium Mahmoud Abd El Aleem Ali Ali El-Remaily a ⁎ H.A. Hamad b ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Sohag University, 82524 Sohag, Egypt Department of Chemistry Faculty of Science Sohag University Sohag 82524 Egypt b Fabrication Technology Research Department, Advanced Technology and New Materials Research Institute (ATNMRI), City of Scientific Research and Technological Applications (SRTA-City), New Borg El-Arab City, P.O. Box 21934, Alexandria, Egypt Fabrication Technology Research Department Advanced Technology and New Materials Research Institute (ATNMRI) City of Scientific Research and Technological Applications (SRTA-City) New Borg El-Arab City P.O. Box 21934 Alexandria Egypt ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +20 1143627127; fax: +20 93601159. Graphical abstract A highly stable CoFe2O4 magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) has been successfully prepared using a combined sonochemical and co-precipitation technique in aqueous medium without any surfactant or organic capping agent. The prepared (MNPs) were characterized with XRD, SEM, EDX, TEM, FT-IR and VSM. These nanoparticles form stable dispersions in aqueous or alcoholic medium. MNPs has been an efficient and environmentally benign nanocatalyst for the one-pot multicomponent synthesis of tetrahydrobenzo[h][1,3] thiazolo[4,5-b]quinolin-9-one 4a-p. The synthesized compounds easy work-up and purification of products by non-chromatographic methods. Highly yield of the corresponding products were obtained within a very short time in presence of just 6mol% of the catalyst. Keywords Superparamagnetic materials Heterogeneous catalysis CoFe2O4MNPs Aqueous medium [1,3] Thiazolo[4,5-b]quinolin-9-one Nanocatalyst Recyclibity non-chromatographic methods 1 Introduction The main objective in the field of catalysis, in terms of green chemistry, is to develop environmentally friendly, practical, facial, clean, economical, selective and efficient processes for catalyst separation and recycling [1]. A possible way of achieving this is the use of magnetic catalyst for various organic synthesis transformations [2]. A magnetic catalyst system provides more effective separation of catalysts rather than traditional filtration and centrifugation methods [3] Magnetic separation provides a convenient method for removing and recycling magnetized species by applying an appropriate magnetic field. Magnetic separation is economical, efficient, simple, and promising for industrial application [4], Furthermore, increasing attention has recently been paid tothe use of nanoparticles (NPs) as a catalyst due to their remarkable advantages such as small size, large specific surface area, high dispersion property, and selectivity, and easily modifiable surface by chemical methods [5]. So, magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) combined with catalysts could not only increase the durability of the catalysts but also help to separate and recycle the catalyst particles [6]. Among the various magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) as the core magnetic supports, cobalt ferrite is one of the most versatile magnetic materials, as it haslarge magnetocrystalline anisotropy [7], high coercivity [8], moderate saturation magnetization [9], large magnetic isotropies, large magneto strictive coefficient [10], chemical stability, mechanical strength [11,12], and is inexpensive; its catalytic activities depends on the tetrahedral and octahedral sites of the spinal structure of ferrite NPs [13]. This kind of ferrite is a spinel, but it exhibits a large coercivity different from the rest of the spinel ferrites [14]. CoFe2O4 has an inverse spinel structure where oxygen atoms make up an FCC lattice and with one half of Fe3+ ions occupying the tetrahedral A sites and the other half, together with Co2+ ions, located at the octahedral B sites. Various synthesis strategies are used for the preparation of MNPs such as chemical co-precipitation [15,16], sol-gel [17], combustion [18], microwave heating [19], micro- and nanoemulsion [20], sonochemical reaction [21], high temperature decomposition [22] and laser pyrolysis [23]. However, in many cases, the NPs get agglomerated with anon-uniform shape, and they cannot be stored for a long period of time, which is a serious disadvantage in their application[24]. The most advantageous method for the production of NPs is coprecipitation. Chemical co-precipitation is the most promising method due to its simplicity, productivity and low cost in the production process. The control of the size, shape and composition of MNPs depends on the type of iron salts used (e.g., chlorides, sulfates, nitrates, perchlorates, etc.) [25], Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio presence or absence of oxygen gas, reaction rate and temperature [26]. In 1997, Alvarez-Ibarra et al., reported the synthesis and cytotoxic evaluation of thiazolo[5,4-b]quinolines, considered isosteric with 9-anilinoacridines, as part of the effort to find better antitumor compounds with fewer side effects [27]. Some thiazolo[5,4-b]quinolines are cytotoxic to several cancer cell lines as well as being DNA intercalators and inhibitors of human topoisomerase II in vitro [28,29]. So, it was decided to synthesize tetrahydrobenzo[h][1,3]thiazolo[4,5-b]quinolin-9-one derivatives by CoFe2O4MNPs in an aqueous medium as an efficient method. In this paper, we used a heterogeneous and magnetically recoverable catalyst for the novel organic synthesis of tetrahydrobenzo [h][1,3]thiazolo[4,5-b]quinolin-9-one derivativesin an aqueous medium. This is a simple procedure for the green synthesis of highly stable, efficient and magnetically recyclable superparamagnetic spinel CoFe2O4 nanoparticles (CNPs) in an aqueous medium without any surfactant or capping agent and by a combined sonochemical and co-precipitation technique. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Chemicals used in this study were of analytical grade. Cobalt nitrate hexa hydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 98%) was supplied from Belami Fine Chemicals (India), Ferrous chloride tetra hydrate (FeCl2·4H2O,99%) was obtained from ACROS chemicals (USA–Belgium), Ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·H2O, min.99%) was obtained from Riedel-dehaen – Sigma–Aldrich chemicals (Switzerland), Sodium hydroxide ([NaOH], min.99%) was supplied from ADWIC El-nasr company for chemicals (Egypt), Absolute ethanol (C2H5OH, 99.9%) was supplied from Sigma–Aldrich (E.U.) and de-ionized water was used. 2.2 Synthesis of superparamagnetic CoFe2O4 nanoparticles by combined sonochemical and co-precipitation Method A combined sonochemical and co-precipitation technique was employed for the synthesis of cobalt–ferrite nanocrystals. A typical synthesis is as follows: an aqueous solution of CoCl2·6H2O, FeSO4·7H2O and Fe2 (SO4)3·7H2O with the same molar ratio of Co2+:Fe2+:Fe3+ dissolved in de-ionized water (18.2MΩcm, TKA-Genpure Instrument) were mixed in a 500mL three neck flask placed in an ultrasonic bath. A NaOH aqueous solution (1.5mol/L) was added drop wise into the above solution under argon atmosphere with continuous ultrasonic irradiation (frequency 40KHz and power of 40KW). The final pH of the solution was 9 to ensure complete precipitation. The resultant slurry was removed from the three neck flask and aged at 40°C for 4h. to increase crystallinity. The final precipitate was filtered, washed with deionized water and ethanol, and dried at 50°C under vacuum for 24h. The obtained prepared sample (1C) was then calcined at 900°C for 1h. resulting in the CoFe2O4NPs (1C1) [30]. 2.3 Synthesis of tetrahydrobenzo[h][1,3]thiazolo[4,5-b]quinolin-9-one derivatives All reagents were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich. Aldehydes were distilled before use. To a solution of α-naphthylamine (1mmol), Aromatic aldehyde (1mmol) and 2,4-thiazolidinedione (1mmol) in a 5mL mixture of water and ethanol (3:1 ratio) in a round-bottom flask, was added cobalt ferrite magnetic catalyst (0.06mmol). The reaction mixture was refluxed at 120°C for the appropriate time. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. After the completion of the reaction, the catalyst was separated magnetically. The reaction mixture was allowed to stand overnight. The solid material was filtered off, washed with water, dried and recrystallized from ethanol to furnish pure tetrahydrobenzo[h][1,3] thiazolo [4,5-b]quinolin-9-one derivatives. 2.4 Instruments The pH was measured by a single electrode pH-meter (Denver Instrument Co., USA). X-ray Diffraction Analysis (XRD) was carried out with a Shimadzu- XRD-7000 Diffractometer (Japan), at room temperature with Cu Kα radiations of wavelength (λ =1.5406Å), generated at 30kV–30mA for cobalt ferrite NPs. Morphology of the synthesized powders was studied with a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) (JEOL JSM-6360 LA, Japan) with a power supply of 30kV. The composition and elemental studies of CoFe2O4MNPs were carried out by Energy Dispersive X-ray (EDX) combined with SEM and Transmission Electron Micro-scope (TEM)(JEOL JEM 1230, Japan) with Max. Mag. 600k× and resolution 0.2nm. Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded by FT-IR Shimadzu-8400 S (Japan) in KBr tablets. Thermal characteristics were measured by Thermogravemetric Analysis (TGA-50H, Shimadzu (Japan)) with heating rate 10°C/min. (30mL/min) up to 600°C under N2. Differential Scanning Calometery (DSC). It was performed with a heat flux Shimadzu DSC-60A, (Japan) in N2 atmosphere, flow rate 30mL/min., temperature range 30–600°C and heating rate 10°C/min. Magnetic characteristics were measured by Vibrating Sample magnetometer (VSM) (Lake Shore- 7410 VSM), magnetic field up to 20 kOe and magnetic moment sensitivity up to 1 memu. Hydrogen and Carbon Proton Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (1H, 13C NMR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX-300 or 400MHz using Tri Methyl Silynate (TMS) as an internal reference and Di Methyl Sulphoxide (DMSO-d6) as a solvent. Mass spectra were performed on a Shimadzu Gas Chromatography- Mass Spectroscopy (GC–MS)GC–MS-QP 1000 mass spectrometer at 70eV. All compounds were checked for their purity on Thin Layer Chromatography (TLC) plates. 3 Result and Discussion. 3.1 Characterization of CoFe2O4Magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) 3.1.1 Structural chracteristics To characterize phase and crystallization of the co-precipitated samples, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed from the obtained CoFe2O4 i.e., the precursors of the magnetic core and their calcined products (without calcinations, 600°C and 900°C for 1h.in air atmosphere) are shown in Fig. 1 . The crystallite size of the cobalt ferrite NPs obtained from the XRD patternusing Scherer’s formula [31] was found to be 37.5nm. This result is consistent with the sizes determined by TEM photo (Fig. 2 ). The CoFe2O4 structure belongs to the inverse spinel group with the general formula A (B2) O4. The peaks appeared at 18.2°, 30.0°, 35.4°, 37.2°, 43.47°, 57.1 and 62.72° are attributed to (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (511) and (440) reflections of the spinel phase of CoFe2O4.These peaks shows that the peaks are in good agreement with the cubic structure [space group: Fd-3m] known from CoFe2O4 crystal(JCPDS No. 003-0864), meaning its high crystallization and few impurities. From Fig. 1a the peak shape of the CoFe2O4 precursor was very wide, and the basic characteristic peak did not appear, which indicated that the crystallization of the precursor was incomplete after drying with a very small crystal size (11.5nm). It was estimated using the Sherrer’s formula that the size of spinel crystal was about 10–12nm (Table 1 ) with a space group of Fd3m, and the amorphous nature disappeared and the diffraction peak of (311) crystal plane appeared. In addition, the peak shape in (Fig. 1b) was relatively narrow and high, which indicates that the crystal grew up with increasing temperature to 900°C, and the crystallization was complete, indicating that the peak intensity increased with increasing calcinations temperature and that crystalline phase of the prepared CoFe2O4 is stable during heat treatment [32]. With the increase ofcalcination temperature, the diffraction peaks increase significantly in sharpness and intensity, indicating the formation of CoFe2O4NPs with greater crystallinity and mean crystallite size. That the full-width at half maximum (FWHM) of the diffraction peaks decreases with increasing annealing temperature discloses that the average crystallite size is becoming bigger correspondingly [33]. Fig. 2a shows SEM images of CoFe2O4MNPs that were prepared by the co-precipitation method. The images have uniform spherical structure morphology with a narrow size distribution of particles. The uniform spherical morphology of NPs was obtained at a temperature 900°C. The product appeared to have a highly spherical morphology with a size of 52–90nm. Fig. 2b depicts the typical TEM images of cubic cobalt ferrite NPs with calcined at 900°C with an average particle size of 50nm. The structural composition was examined was examined by EDX as shown in Fig. 3 . Only three kinds of elements, Co, Fe, O (11.31, 25.51, 63.18wt.%, respectively) were detected and their mass ratios correspond to the CoFe2O4 chemical composition EDX spectra of products that used the NaOH solution in the co-precipitation process. The EDX results showed that all products did not contain the element of Na .The atomic ratio of Fe: Co for the entire calcined sample is maintained at ∼2:1. This result indicated that the Na cations did not take part in the reaction. These results revealed the sustained spinel structure of the CoFe2O4 crystal with a calcinations temperature of 900°C. Fig. 4 displays the FT-IR spectra of CoFe2O4 before and after calcinations treatment at 900°C. The characteristic vibration around (3500cm−1) and deformation at (1600cm−1) bands of water and nitrate bands (1360cm−1) are intense in the spectrum a (non-calcined sample), and disappear when the samples are calcined at temperatures above 600°C. A band centered around 1383cm−1, indicates the presence of NO3 − ions (NO stretching vibrations) [34] and CH group compounds (CH bending vibrations) in the gel [35]. From Fig. 4b, the broad band with low intensity at 3400cm−1 confirms the presence of hydroxyl group on iron oxide surface. Bands at about 561cm−1 correspond to FeO vibration modes. At the same time metal-oxide vibration bands characteristic of cobalt ferrite (580 and 370cm−1) increase, corroborating the spinel structure characteristics of cobalt ferrite, assigned the high-frequency bands to the tetrahedral group (575cm−1region) and the low frequency bands to octahedral group (374cm−1) [36]. 3.1.2 Thermal characteristics The stability of the co-precipitated CoFe2O4MNPs was determined using TGA with flow rate N2 of 20mL per minute as shown in Fig. 5 . Three stages of weight loss are observed. The first thermal event in the temperature range of 25–120°C was associated with the dehydration of the sample, with weight loss of 7.8%. The second thermal event occurring in the temperature range between 120 and 270°C was attributed to the decomposition of nitrates (7.2% weight loss) and the starting of cobalt ferrite crystallization. The other event between 269 and 600°C was attributed to the loss of structural water. Above 600°C, no weight loss was observed and the crystallization process was finished. In the DSC curve, an exothermic peak appeared at 71°C and extended to 127°C with a maximum at 113.23°C. This was attributed to hydration and loss of water with specific of heat 30.13J /g and complete crystallization of CoFe2O4 due to a sharp exothermic peak (Fig. 6 ). Then, aweak exothermic peak from 170°C extended to 201.80°C with a maximum 15.33J/g. The decomposition of organic species also gradually gave rise to a smaller, weaker and broader exothermic peak at 550°C in the DSC curve. 3.1.3 Magnetic characteristics The magnetic properties of as-prepared CoFe2O4 NPs and calcined at 900 °C were investigated with a quantum magnetometer by a VSM (vibrating sample magnetometer) at 300K (T > T B) with a maximum applied field up to 20kOe as shown in Fig. 7 and Table 2 . The corecivity (Hc) is shown to be about 0.0237 and 1.114kOe. The saturation magnetization (M s) values of about 13.6 and 65.09emu/g indicative of strong soft magnetic properties [37] and the remenant magnetization (M r) is 0.3and 21.79emu/g, for CoFe2O4 as prepared and calcined at 900°C, respectively, as illustrated in Table 2. The saturation magnetization and remenant magnetization increased with increasing heat-treatment temperatures. This happened because of the incomplete crystallization and small particle size after treating at low temperatures. Meanwhile, other factors such as the large proportion of surface atoms, the unsaturated ligand, and the strong thermal disturbance characteristics could play a role. Therefore, the magnetic structure of the crystal was unstable and disordered and the magnetic moment cannot be easily kept consistent with the external field. In addition, because the powder surface had a non-magnetic layer, and the proportion of the layer decreased with increasing the particle size, the saturated magnetization can increase with particles size. Furthermore, the crystal structure will not be changed by the applied magnetic field and pressures [38]. The sample is found to be super paramagnetic from the complete reversibility of the M–H curve recorded at room temperature. The decrease in the density of magnetization with the decrease in the average diameter of the nanocrystallites can be attributed to surface effects and core-shell morphology [39].The magnetic properties of super paramagnetic nanomaterials are very sensitive to the morphologies and structures CoFe2O4MNPs.The corecivity behavior indicates that Co atoms in the Fe-O matrix increase magnetic anisotropy of the material [40]. It is well known that the surface spin disorder enhancing caused by the decreasing of particles size and the coercivity would approach zero under a short thermal fluctuation (so called super paramagnetism) if the crystal size is small enough [41]. 3.2 Catalytic activity On the basis of exhaustive literature review, it has been found that thiazolo[5,4-b]quinolines, have good potential to exhibit anticancer activity. So, it was decided to study the application of the catalyst for first time synthesis of highly substituted tetrahydrobenzo[h][1,3] thiazolo[4,5-b]quinolin-9-one 4a-p as a excellent yields, simple, mild, expeditious and an environmentally method. When reacted α-naphthylamine 1 with Aromatic aldehyde 2 and 2,4-thiazolidinedione 3 in mixture of water and ethanol (3:1 ratio). (Scheme 1 ,Table 3 ). Designing organic reactions in aqueous media is another attractive area in green chemistry. Water is an abundant and environmentally benign solvent. This protocol offers flexibility in tuning the molecular complexity and diversity. The reactions proceeded to completion almost instantaneously, and a pure product was obtained, without using any chromatographic techniques, simply by recrystallization from ethanol. In order to standardize the reaction, α-naphthylamine (1mmol), 4-chlorobenzaldehyde (1mmol) and 2,4-thiazolidinedione(1mmol) were dissolved in a mixture of water and ethanol (3:1 ratio) in the absence of the catalyst, no product was obtained (Table 4 , entry 1). The reaction mixture worked by using different types of catalysts were examined, i.e., CoCl2·6.H2O, Co(NO2)2·6.H2O,FeCl36.H2O, CoO powder, CoO MNPs, Fe3O4 powder, Fe3O4MNPs, CoFe2O4 powder, CoFe2O4MNPs, calcined Fe3O4MNPs, calcined CoFe2O4MNPs at 600°C, calcined CoFe2O4MNPs at 900°C fresh and calcined recovered CoFe2O4MNPs. The highest yield of product in the shortest time was obtained using, calcinedCoFe2O4MNPs which may be due to greater diffusion of calcined CoFe2O4NPs in the reaction mixture. The recovered catalyst was found to be similar to the fresh calcined CoFe2O4 MNPs. (Table 4, entry 2–14). The best result was obtained with 6mol% calcined CoFe2O4-MNPs. These results are consistent with the results of XRD analysis. The crystallite size increases with increasing of calcination temperature; this is forced condensation of free OH groups on the surface of CoFe2O4 and increased the catalytic activity. Reaction in magnetically recoverable 6mol% calcined CoFe2O4MNPs produced the high yield. The reaction yield with increasing amount of calcined CoFe2O4-MNPs was not substantially increased. (Table 4, entry 15–22). We also tried different solvents such as water, Ethanol, Methanol, DMF, THF, DCM, 1,4-dioxane, MeCN and toluene under similar reaction conditions were obtained lower yields comparing to mixture of water and ethanol (3:1 ratio) (Table 4, entry 23–31). 3.3 Recyclability of the catalyst Another important advantage of this protocol was the stability, recyclability and reusability of the present heterogeneous calcined CoFe2O4nanocatalyst. After completion of the reaction, the nanocatalyst was isolated by a physical magnetic separation and washed with ethanol, dried at 60°C under vacuum to remove residual solvents. The SEM, XRD and FT-IR analysis of the nanoparticle revealed that the morphology of the recovered MNPs remains unaltered during the recycling process which indicates that the catalysts stable during the reaction (see Supplementary data Figs. 10,11,12). It was used directly for 6 times in other fresh reactions under similar conditions without the loss of efficiency (Figs. 8 and 9 , ). A possible mechanism for the formation of products 4 a-p in the presence of a catalytic amount of calcined CoFe2O4 MNPs is shown in (Scheme 2 ). The reaction presumably proceeds via the reaction of an aldehyde 2 and 2,4-thiazolidinedione 3 by a Knoevenagel condensation reaction to produce an α,β-unsaturated ketone 5. Next, it could undergo a Michael-type addition reaction with α-naphthylamine 1 to form compound 6. Then, the adduct 6 was cyclized by an intramolecular nucleophilic attack and losing an H2O molecule to afford the tetraheterocyclic products 4a-p . See (Scheme 2). 4 Conclusions In conclusion,CoFe2O4 highly stable magnetic nanocatalyst has been demonstrated as an efficient and environmentally benign nanocatalyst with average sizes in the range 37nm using a combined sonochemical and co-precipitation process for the one-pot multicomponent synthesis of tetrahydrobenzo[h][1,3] thiazolo[4,5-b]quinolin-9-one 4a-p . The as calcined CoFe2O4MNPs showed high superpara magnetic properties, chemical and thermal stability with high values of corecivity, saturation and remenant magnetization. This protocol includes several key advantages over existing protocols such as avoiding hazardous organic solvents and toxic catalysts, reusability of the catalyst, simple and readily available precursors, easy work-up procedure, short reaction times, good to high yields, and mild reaction conditions. Acknowledgments The authors are deeply gratitude to both Sohag University and City of Scientific Research and Technological Applications (SRTA-City) in Egypt for supporting and facilitating this study. coredata.dc:description: A highly stable CoFe2O4 magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) has been successfully prepared using a combined sonochemical and co-precipitation technique in aqueous medium without any surfactant or organic capping agent. The prepared (MNPs) were characterized with XRD, SEM, EDX, TEM, FT-IR and VSM. These nanoparticles form stable dispersions in aqueous or alcoholic medium. MNPs has been an efficient and environmentally benign nanocatalyst for the one-pot multicomponent synthesis of tetrahydrobenzo[h][1,3] thiazolo[4,5-b]quinolin-9-one 4a-p. The synthesized compounds easy work-up and purification of products by non-chromatographic methods. Highly yield of the corresponding products were obtained within a very short time in presence of just 6mol% of the catalyst.

dc:creator.$: Abd El Aleem Ali Ali El-Remaily, Mahmoud

coredata.dc:title: Synthesis and characterization of highly stable superparamagnetic CoFe2O4 nanoparticles as a catalyst for novel synthesis of thiazolo[4,5-b]quinolin-9-one derivatives in aqueous medium
